filename: 2019., Chaobo Zhang, An improved association rule mining-based method for revealing operational problems of building heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems.pdf
title: An improved association rule mining-based method for revealing operational problems of building heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) systems
author: Chaobo Zhang
subject: Applied Energy, 253 (2019) 113492. doi:10.1016/j.apenergy.2019.113492
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: The paper proposes an improved association rule mining-based method to reveal operational problems in building heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. The approach uses kernel density estimation-based data transformation and association rule comparison-based post-mining to identify abnormal rules revealing issues like faulty sensors and inefficient energy distribution.
methodology: The methodology involves kernel density estimation for outlier identification and data transformation into categorical data through classification, category fusion, and transformation steps. Association rule mining is used to discover relationships between variables using algorithms like FP-growth. The approach also includes a post-mining step to analyze association rules with thresholds set for support, confidence, and lift.
future_recommendations: Future work could include applying the proposed method to other energy systems, such as solar radiation forecasting or wind farm performance analysis. Additionally, exploring the use of data-driven methodologies in wastewater treatment plants or electric vehicle charging demand characterization could be beneficial.

title: A Reversible Residual Network-Aided Canonical Correlation Analysis to Fault Detection and Diagnosis in Electrical Drive Systems
subject: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement;2024;73; ;10.1109/TIM.2023.3348900
creator: LaTeX with hyperref
overall_summary: A novel approach to fault detection and diagnosis in electrical drive systems using a reversible residual network-aided canonical correlation analysis (RRNCCA) is proposed. The method reformulates the objective function of CCA and applies it for fault diagnosis, showing improved performance over traditional linear methods.
methodology: The RRNCCA-based FDD method uses a reversible loop to extract correlation between nonlinear variables and is designed to improve the fault detection ability of test statistics. Offline training involves loading data, defining neural network parameters, constructing the network, obtaining optimal weights, generating residual signals, calculating threshold, and declaring FDD. Online application includes reading online signal, calculating four residual signals in real-time, generating T? test statistics, declaring FD, diagnosing faults, and repeating if system is fault-free.
future_recommendations: Future work could include exploring the application of RRNCCA to other complex systems, such as high-speed trains or power grids. Additionally, further research on improving the robustness of the method against noise and uncertainties in the data would be beneficial.

filename: Autonomous fault detection and diagnosis for permanent magnet synchronous motors using combined variational mode decomposition, the hilbert-huang transform, and a CNN.pdf
title: Autonomous fault detection and diagnosis for permanent magnet synchronous motors using combined variational mode decomposition, the Hilbert-Huang transform, and a convolutional neural network
author: Ma'd El-Dalahmeh
subject: Computers and Electrical Engineering, 110 (2023) 108894. doi:10.1016/j.compeleceng.2023.108894
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: The paper proposes a novel fault detection and diagnosis technique for permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) using built-in sensors. The method combines variational mode decomposition, Hilbert-Huang transform, and convolutional neural network to detect three types of faults: inter-turn short circuit, partial demagnetization, and static eccentricity. The proposed method achieves high accuracy in detecting and classifying faults under various operating conditions.
methodology: The methodology involves combining variational mode decomposition (VMD), Hilbert-Huang transform (HHT), and convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect and diagnose faults in PMSMs. The VMD process involves calculating the analytic function using Hilbert transform, demodulating each frequency mode spectrum, and taking the resultant signal's derivative and squared L2-norm.
future_recommendations: Future work includes addressing potential issues like data degeneracy through diverse training data and validating the algorithm using performance metrics. Additionally, exploring other techniques for condition monitoring and fault diagnosis in PMSMs can lead to improved reliability, detection accuracy, reduced maintenance costs, increased safety, better decision-making, and optimised asset management.

filename: Digital twin enabled FDD process for building HVAC systems.pdf
title: Digital twin enabled fault detection and diagnosis process for building HVAC systems
author: Xiang Xie
subject: Automation in Construction, 146 (2023) 104695. doi:10.1016/j.autcon.2022.104695
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: The paper proposes a digital twin-enabled fault detection and diagnosis process for building HVAC systems using symbolic artificial intelligence to identify informative sensory dimensions for building-specific faults and define machine-readable fault tags to label corresponding sensor entities. The approach leverages semantics in BIM models, graph-based semantic web, and domain-specific ontologies to reduce data complexity while preserving relevant information.
methodology: The methodology involves implementing a digital twin enabled FDD process using knowledge tags to label sensors and preserve ad-hoc temporal knowledge to customize data pipelines for FDD. The study uses Symbolic Aggregate approXimation (SAX) to select relevant sensory dimensions from labelled data, assuming a large number of sensors in HVAC systems generate massive amounts of data.
future_recommendations: Future work includes exploring the application of digital twin technology in building energy management and fault detection, as well as integrating energy management tools with digital twins for smart energy systems. Additionally, the concept of the semantic web is introduced, as well as a combined data-driven and model-based residual selection algorithm for fault detection and isolation.

filename: Improving the efficiency of fan coil units in hotel buildings through deep-learning-based fault detection.pdf
title: Improving the Efficiency of Fan Coil Units in Hotel Buildings through Deep-Learning-Based Fault Detection
author: Iva Matetić, Ivan Štajduhar, Igor Wolf, and Sandi Ljubic
subject: Optimizing the performance of heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems is critical in today's energy-conscious world. Fan coil units (FCUs) play a critical role in providing comfort in various environments as an important component of HVAC systems. However, FCUs often experience failures that affect their efficiency and increase their energy consumption. In this context, deep learning (DL)-based fault detection offers a promising solution. By detecting faults early and preventing system failures, the efficiency of FCUs can be improved. This paper explores DL models as fault detectors for FCUs to enable smarter and more energy-efficient hotel buildings. We tested three contemporary DL modeling approaches: convolutional neural network (CNN), long short-term memory network (LSTM), and a combination of CNN and gated recurrent unit (GRU). The random forest model (RF) was additionally developed as a baseline benchmark. The fault detectors were tested on a real-world dataset obtained from the sensory measurement system installed in a hotel and additionally supplemented with simulated data via a physical model developed in TRNSYS. Three representative FCU faults, namely, a stuck valve, a reduction in airflow, and an FCU outage, were simulated with a much larger dataset than is typically utilized in similar studies. The results showed that the hybrid model, integrating CNN and GRU, performed best for all three observed faults. DL-based fault detectors outperformed the baseline RF model, confirming these solutions as viable components for energy-efficient hotels.
creator: LaTeX with hyperref
overall_summary: The paper discusses improving fan coil unit (FCU) efficiency in hotel buildings through deep-learning-based fault detection. Three DL models (CNN, LSTM, and CNN-GRU hybrid) were tested on a real-world dataset from a sensory measurement system and simulated data, outperforming a baseline random forest model for detecting three representative FCU faults: stuck valve, reduced airflow, and FCU outage.
methodology: The study used a dataset collected from a hotel in Zagreb, Croatia, utilizing a smart-room system for monitoring and regulation. The data was acquired from 2015 to 2021 with a sampling frequency of 5 minutes, focusing on years 2017-2019 due to higher quality and representativeness. The physical model was developed using TRNSYS software and a corresponding hotel building architectural description, simulating thermal behavior in six zones.
future_recommendations: The authors suggest that future work could focus on expanding the dataset to include more diverse FCU types and fault scenarios, as well as exploring the application of DL models to other HVAC sub-systems. Additionally, they recommend further research into the integration of DL models with traditional FDD methods for improved accuracy and robustness.

filename: Fault detection and diagnosis for Air Handling Unit based on multiscale convolutional neural networks.pdf
title: Fault detection and diagnosis for Air Handling Unit based on multiscale convolutional neural networks
author: Fanyong Cheng
subject: Energy & Buildings, 236 (2021) 110795. doi:10.1016/j.enbuild.2021.110795
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: The paper proposes a novel fault detection and diagnosis (FDD) method using multiscale convolutional neural networks (MCNNs) for Air Handling Unit (AHU) systems. The MCNNs-based FDD method uses three different scale kernels to improve feature extraction and end-to-end learning strategy optimizes the model. The proposed method is evaluated on an air handling unit experiment platform with a total dataset of 6048 data segments, including samples from normal operating conditions and four fault scenarios. The results show that the MCNNs method achieves the best overall performance with an F1-score of 0.989 or higher for all kinds of faults, outperforming other methods.
methodology: The proposed MCNNs-based FDD method uses a multi-scale convolutional neural network (MCNNs) model to automatically learn high-level discriminative features from multiscale monitoring signals, improving fault diagnosis performance. The model consists of three subparts: input, multiscale feature extraction, and classification. The input is an 8x8 matrix representing 8 monitoring signals with a length of 8 samples each. The model uses convolutional layers with hyperparameters such as kernel size, number of kernels, padding, and stride to extract features from the input data.
future_recommendations: The scalability of the proposed MCNNs method will be verified on imbalanced data distribution to mitigate the impact of skewed data between normal and fault data, aiming to improve its general performance.

filename: Novel Actuator Fault Diagnosis Framework for Multizone HVAC Systems Using 2-D Convolutional Neural Networks.pdf
title: Novel Actuator Fault Diagnosis Framework for Multizone HVAC Systems Using 2-D Convolutional Neural Networks
subject: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering; ;PP;99;10.1109/TASE.2021.3067866
creator: Appligent AppendPDF Pro 5.5
overall_summary: A novel fault diagnosis framework for multizone HVAC systems using 2D convolutional neural networks (CNNs) is proposed. The approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of accuracy, precision, and recall. The framework is tested through simulations and demonstrates improved performance with an average sensitivity of 99%. Future work includes considering multiple actuator faults, developing simultaneous sensor and actuator FD strategies, and conducting energy performance assessments to demonstrate the diagnosis approach's capability in improving system efficiency.
methodology: The proposed framework uses a multimodel approach composed of five two-class CNNs for fault detection and diagnosis. The 1-D-to-2-D data transformation technique is used to enable the use of a 2-D CNN-based diagnosis approach with 1-D signals. Bayesian optimization tunes network parameters, including filter size k and dilation factor fp, reducing the hyperparameter space for S.
future_recommendations: Future work includes considering multiple actuator faults, developing simultaneous sensor and actuator FD strategies, and conducting energy performance assessments to demonstrate the diagnosis approach's capability in improving system efficiency.

filename: A data-driven approach for FD in multi-zone HVAC systems Deep neural bilienar Koopman parity.pdf
title: A data-driven approach for fault diagnosis in multi-zone HVAC systems: Deep neural bilinear Koopman parity
author: Fatemeh Negar Irani
subject: Journal of Building Engineering, 76 (2023) 107127. doi:10.1016/j.jobe.2023.107127
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: The paper presents a novel data-driven approach for fault diagnosis in multi-zone HVAC systems using deep neural bilinear Koopman parity. The method diagnoses various types of sensor faults, including additive, multiplicative, and complete failure, without prior knowledge of HVAC dynamics or fault properties. The proposed method outperforms other models in terms of long-term prediction with lower dimension, while EDMD-based linear and deep linear models have limited precision and reliability.
methodology: The methodology involves integrating bilinear Koopman model realization, deep learning, and parity-space to detect and isolate various types of sensor faults. The proposed structure consists of a linear layer forming the Koopman operator and a lifting encoder that lifts states to a new basis, which can be trained synchronously.
future_recommendations: Future work includes exploring the application of the proposed method to other HVAC systems, investigating the impact of different fault scenarios on the performance of the proposed method, and developing more advanced techniques for handling complex fault types.

filename: 2021., Chaobo Zhang, Analytic hierarchy process-based fuzzy post mining method for operation anomaly detection of building energy systems.pdf
title: Analytic hierarchy process-based fuzzy post mining method for operation anomaly detection of building energy systems
author: Chaobo Zhang
subject: Energy & Buildings, 252 (2021) 111426. doi:10.1016/j.enbuild.2021.111426
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: A novel AHP-based fuzzy post mining method is proposed to detect operation anomalies in building energy systems and enhance energy efficiency. The method evaluates association rules using three criteria (stability, physical correlation, and statistical correlation) and six sub-criteria, successfully removing 95.45% of worthless rules and identifying 93.51% of valuable ones.
methodology: The proposed method uses a four-level hierarchical structure for association rule grading, with weights determined by expert pair-wise comparison matrices. The method also introduces fuzzy set theory into Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to improve the reliability of value grading in association rule mining by considering uncertainties from imprecise judgments.
future_recommendations: Future work includes enhancing the performance of isolating valuable association rules from worthless ones in building lighting systems, exploring new criteria for operation anomaly detection, and applying the proposed method to various types of building energy systems.

filename: Fault Detection and Diagnosis in AHU System with Data Driven.pdf
title: Fault Detection and Diagnosis in AHU System with Data Driven Approaches
author: Yanis Masdoua; Moussa Boukhnifer; Kondo H. Adjallah
subject: 2022 8th International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies (CoDIT);2022;1; ;10.1109/CoDIT55151.2022.9803907
creator: PaperCept Conference Management System
overall_summary: The paper presents a data-driven approach for detecting and diagnosing sensor faults in Air Handling Unit (AHU) systems using Decision Tree, Random Forest, and SVM algorithms. The research aims to reduce energy consumption by identifying temperature sensor faults with high accuracy, achieving 96% accuracy with the Random Forest method.
methodology: The paper uses a data-driven approach, specifically classification techniques using Decision Trees, Random Forest, and SVM algorithms. The methodology includes feature selection based on correlation with the objective of classification to maximize performance and reduce training time. Experimental results are presented using k-Fold cross-validation with k=10 to validate the model.
future_recommendations: Future research plans to generalize fault detection and diagnosis in AHUs, considering various types of faults.

filename: 2019.,Chakraborty, Early detection of faults in HVAC systems using an XGBoost model with a dynamic threshold.pdf
title: Early detection of faults in HVAC systems using an XGBoost model with a dynamic threshold
author: Debaditya Chakraborty
subject: Energy & Buildings, 185 (2019) 326-344. doi:10.1016/j.enbuild.2018.12.032
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: The paper proposes a data-driven model using XGBoost to detect faults in HVAC systems. The dynamic threshold method improves upon traditional methods by adjusting a threshold based on real-time moving averages and standard deviations of predictions, resulting in earlier and more accurate fault detection.
methodology: The research uses a combination of techniques including XGBoost algorithm, recursive equations for dynamic residual evaluation, principal component analysis, Q-statistics, auto-regressive Kalman filter-based model, Bayesian networks, and semi-supervised and hybrid models. Synthetic data is used to develop and evaluate the fault detection model.
future_recommendations: Future work includes establishing desirable ranges of free parameters for different building groups and HVAC systems.

filename: Hybrid Random Forest and Support Vector Machine Modeling for HVAC Fault Detection and Diagnosis.pdf
title: Hybrid Random Forest and Support Vector Machine Modeling for HVAC Fault Detection and Diagnosis
author: Wunna Tun, Johnny Kwok-Wai Wong and Sai-Ho Ling
subject: The malfunctioning of the heating, ventilating, and air conditioning (HVAC) system is considered to be one of the main challenges in modern buildings. Due to the complexity of the building management system (BMS) with operational data input from a large number of sensors used in HVAC system, the faults can be very difficult to detect in the early stage. While numerous fault detection and diagnosis (FDD) methods with the use of statistical modeling and machine learning have revealed prominent results in recent years, early detection remains a challenging task since many current approaches are unfeasible for diagnosing some HVAC faults and have accuracy performance issues. In view of this, this study presents a novel hybrid FDD approach by combining random forest (RF) and support vector machine (SVM) classifiers for the application of FDD for the HVAC system. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed hybrid random forest–support vector machine (HRF–SVM) outperforms other methods with higher prediction accuracy (98%), despite that the fault symptoms were insignificant. Furthermore, the proposed framework can reduce the significant number of sensors required and work well with the small number of faulty training data samples available in real-world applications.
creator: LaTeX with hyperref
overall_summary: The paper proposes a hybrid random forest-support vector machine (HRF-SVM) approach for HVAC fault detection and diagnosis, which outperforms other methods with 98% prediction accuracy. The study highlights the limitations of traditional rule-based threshold approaches and the need for more effective fault detection and diagnosis methods.
methodology: The proposed HRF-SVM method combines random forest (RF) and support vector machine (SVM) classifiers to automatically generate significant features, reduce sensor requirements, and effectively handle imbalanced input data from building management systems (BMS). The experiment used data from the ASHRAE RP-1312 project to test a hybrid approach, collecting sensor readings from various sensors every minute over 24 hours.
future_recommendations: Future work could focus on improving the accuracy of fault detection and diagnosis for specific HVAC components, such as outside air dampers stuck in completely open or closed positions. Additionally, exploring other machine learning algorithms and techniques to further improve performance.

filename: An explainable one-dimensional convolutional neural networks based fault diagnosis method for building heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems.pdf
title: An explainable one-dimensional convolutional neural networks based fault diagnosis method for building heating, ventilation and air conditioning systems
author: Guannan Li
subject: Building and Environment, 203 (2021) 108057. doi:10.1016/j.buildenv.2021.108057
creator: Elsevier
overall_summary: A novel explainable deep learning-based fault diagnosis method is proposed for building heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. The method achieves over 98.5% accuracy in diagnosing seven chiller faults from the ASHRAE research project RP-1043 dataset.
methodology: The paper proposes a novel deep neural network for HVAC fault diagnosis, which uses softsign activation function and excludes pooling layers, and introduces Absolute Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-Absolute-CAM) for visualizing diagnosis criteria. The model is validated on a chiller system from ASHRAE research project 1043.
future_recommendations: Future work includes exploring the application of this method to other HVAC systems, as well as investigating the impact of sensor validation and feature engineering on fault detection and diagnosis performance.

filename: An Online Data-Driven Fault Diagnosis Method for Air Handling Units by Rule and Convolutional Neural Networks.pdf
title: An Online Data-Driven Fault Diagnosis Method for Air Handling Units by Rule and Convolutional Neural Networks
author: Huanyue Liao, Wenjian Cai, Fanyong Cheng, Swapnil Dubey and Pudupadi Balachander Rajesh
subject: The stable operation of air handling units (AHU) is critical to ensure high efficiency and to extend the lifetime of the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems of buildings. In this paper, an online data-driven diagnosis method for AHU in an HVAC system is proposed and elaborated. The rule-based method can roughly detect the sensor condition by setting threshold values according to prior experience. Then, an efficient feature selection method using 1D convolutional neural networks (CNNs) is proposed for fault diagnosis of AHU in HVAC systems according to the system’s historical data obtained from the building management system. The new framework combines the rule-based method and CNNs-based method (RACNN) for sensor fault and complicated fault. The fault type of AHU can be accurately identified via the offline test results with an accuracy of 99.15% and fast online detection within 2 min. In the lab, the proposed RACNN method was validated on a real AHU system. The experimental results show that the proposed RACNN improves the performance of fault diagnosis.
creator: LaTeX with hyperref
overall_summary: A novel online fault diagnosis method, RACNN, is proposed for air handling units (AHUs) in heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) systems. The method combines rule-based and convolutional neural network (CNN)-based approaches to detect sensor faults and complicated faults with an accuracy of 99.15% within 2 minutes.
methodology: The proposed RACNN method involves collecting historical data, filtering out noise using a one-dimensional non-local means filtering algorithm, and then analyzing the filtered data using the RACNN approach for initial fault diagnosis and detection. The method also uses rule-based diagnosis techniques to determine fault detection thresholds.
future_recommendations: Future work includes exploring the application of the proposed RACNN method to other HVAC systems and equipment, as well as investigating the use of transfer learning to improve the accuracy and speed of the method.
